entry.title: Holmes jury keeps execution as option as sentencing advances
entry.summary: Robert and Arlene Holmes testified that they never suspected their son was mentally ill.

entry.title: Jury leaves door open to death penalty for Colorado theatre killer James Holmes
entry.summary:
? Jurors in the Colorado theatre shooting trial declined to rule out the death penalty Monday as they move toward sentencing James Holmes, finding his defence failed to persuade them to show him mercy.

The same jury last month convicted Holmes of killing 12 people and injuring 70 in the July 2012 attack at a suburban Denver movie theatre.

entry.title: Jury resumes death penalty deliberations for Colorado theater shooter James Holmes
entry.summary:
Jurors must decide whether there are any reasons, such as Holmes' mental illness and his trouble-free youth, that mean he should be sentenced to life in prison without parole instead of to death.

If jurors unanimously agree that such factors outweigh the heinousness of the July 2012 attack that killed 12 people and injured 70 others, Holmes would be sentenced to a life term.

entry.title: Deliberations resume in Colorado theater shooting trial
entry.summary: The jury in the Colorado theater shooting trial resumed deliberating Monday whether to keep the death penalty on the table for gunman James Holmes.

entry.title: Batman shooter James Holmes' father narrates a parent's worst nightmare
entry.summary: James Holmes in 2013.

entry.title: Batman shooter James Holmes' father narrates a parent's worst nightmare
entry.summary: Robert Holmes: "Yes he is."

entry.title: Holmes' father says he worried when son stopped calling
entry.summary: "He told us he loved us, but I could see there was something really wrong with him," Robert Holmes said.

entry.title: Holmes' father says he worried when son stopped calling
entry.summary: Robert Holmes said he has seen James Holmes in jail only three times because his son typically does not allow visitors.

entry.title: Holmes' father says he worried when son stopped calling
entry.summary:
A photo showing James Holmes is displayed on a monitor.

She told them James Holmes was dropping out of his prestigious neuroscience graduate school program.

entry.title: Father of James Holmes thought 'he might be depressed'
entry.summary:
The father of Colorado theater shooter James Holmes said he didn't know his son suffered from mental illness until he killed 12 people at a Batman movie.

On the first point, the defense brought back the same court-appointed psychiatrist who found Holmes was legally sane during the attack, this time to say that it was severe mental illness that drove Holmes to kill.

entry.title: Father of James Holmes thought 'he might be depressed'
entry.summary:
Robert Holmes said he wasn't aware of mental illness in the family until investigators researched it in preparation for this trial.

"I assumed he might be depressed," Robert Holmes said.

entry.title: 'Tonight': Say Anything with Katie Holmes
Jimmy Fallon Mangles Katie Holmes’s Face
Colorado theater shooter deserves to die, prosecutors say
entry.summary: The monthlong penalty phase of the trial of Holmes, who could be sentenced to death for killing 12 people in a Colorado movie theater, began Wednesday morning with the judge giving instructions to the jury.

entry.title: The Latest: Colorado shooting jurors to review Holmes video
entry.summary:
The jurors were given permission to view a recording of Holmes after the shooting in which he asks police officers if any children were hurt.

Lawyers for Colorado theater shooter James Holmes did not make any arguments disputing that the crime makes him eligible for the death penalty.

The penalty phase of the trial starts Wednesday with prosecutors telling jurors why Holmes should be eligible for execution.

entry.title: Colorado theater shooter deserves to die, prosecutors say
entry.summary: (AP) - James Holmes should be put to death for the Colorado theater shooting because he deliberately and cruelly killed 12 people, including a 6-year-old girl, prosecutors told jurors Wednesday.

entry.title: Prosecutors say Holmes deserves to die for theater shootings
entry.summary:
The same jurors who convicted Holmes of murder and attempted murder last week - swiftly dismissing his claim that he was legally insane during the attack - must now decide whether to sentence him to death or life in prison without parole.

Already, a fifth-grade teacher who gave videotaped testimony early because he was unavailable during sentencing repeatedly referred to Holmes as "Jimmy" and described him as a bright student with a big smile.

Jurors would then deliberate for a second time, to decide whether, beyond a reasonable doubt, the mitigating factors so outweigh the aggravating factors that Holmes deserves life without parole rather than execution.

entry.title: 'Mr. Holmes' meets his match in Mr. McKellen
entry.summary:
"I have been alone, all my life," says 93-year-old Sherlock Holmes (Ian McKellen), and you hear every one of his years in that voice.

"Mr. Holmes," directed by Bill Condon and based on a novel by Mitch Cullin, isn't really a mystery, though it presents a few puzzles to solve; instead, it's a gentle examining of life near its end.

entry.title: Holmes will join many other mentally ill inmates in prison
entry.summary:
Despite having convicted Holmes in the killings, jurors must still determine whether to put Holmes on death row for opening fire in the crowded movie theater.

Experts say prisons are ill-equipped to treat the growing number of inmates with mental illnesses - especially the majority who are not convicted of crimes as violent as Holmes, who was diagnosed with a form of schizophrenia.

Even if they decide Holmes should be executed, as prosecutors want, he would spend years in prison as his mandatory appeals play out in court.

entry.title: Ian McKellen delivers in 'Mr. Holmes'
Despite quick conviction, theater shooting trial isn't over
entry.summary: The 27-year-old Holmes, who had been working toward his Ph.D. in neuroscience, could get the death penalty for the massacre that left 12 people dead and dozens of others wounded early Friday, July 20, 2012.

entry.title: Despite quick conviction, theater shooting trial isn't over
entry.summary: The 27-year-old Holmes could get the death penalty for the killing spree that left 12 people dead and dozens of others wounded.

entry.title: Despite quick conviction, trial of Colorado theater shooter James Holmes is far from over
entry.summary:
- Families of the 12 people James Holmes killed and the scores he injured in a packed movie theater were relieved that jurors only needed 12 hours to reject the idea that he was legally insane when he opened fire.

Now the trial enters a new phase as the jury decides whether Holmes should die for his crimes.

entry.title: Despite quick conviction, trial of Colorado theater shooter James Holmes is far from over
entry.summary: Dressed in a blue shirt and khakis, and flanked by his public defenders, Holmes stood impassively with his hands in his pockets the whole time.

entry.title: Colorado movie massacre gunman found guilty of multiple murders
entry.summary: "That guy, sitting right there," he said, pointing at Holmes.

entry.title: Colorado movie massacre gunman found guilty of multiple murders
entry.summary:
After a three-month trial in which they were presented with thousands of pieces of evidence and testimony from hundreds of witnesses, jurors deliberated for about a day and a half, then found Holmes guilty on all 165 counts against him.

Holmes showed no reaction.

entry.title: Colorado theater shooter James Holmes guilty of murder
entry.summary: That Holmes was the lone gunman was never in doubt.

entry.title: Colorado theatre shooter James Holmes guilty of murder
entry.summary: Movie massacre gunman James Holmes was found guilty of multiple counts of murder for the 2012 shooting at a Batman film.

entry.title: Jury Convicts Colorado Theater Shooter of Murder
entry.summary:
James Holmes has been found guilty of murder.

A jury has found Colorado theater shooter James Holmes guilty of murder in the methodically planned attack that left 12 dead and dozens wounded.

entry.title: Batman shooter trial: James Holmes verdict - live
entry.summary: Holmes killed 12 people and wounded a further 70.

entry.title: Jury reaches verdict in Colorado theater shooting trial
entry.summary: Jurors have reached a verdict in the trial of Colorado theater shooter James Holmes.

entry.title: Batman cinema shootings: Colorado jury reaches verdict
entry.summary:
If the jury convicts Holmes, the trial will enter a sentencing phase in which the jurors will hear evidence and decide whether he should be sent to prison for life without the possibility of parole or sentenced to death.

Prosecutors honed in on Holmes' elaborate planning of the massacre.

entry.title: The detective with a new wrinkle in ?Mr. Holmes?
entry.summary: And if they think of Holmes, they will think of Holmes thinking of her.

entry.title: Jury reaches verdict in James Holmes murder trial
entry.summary: Holmes is accused of opening fire during a midnight screening of the Batman movie "The Dark Knight Rises."

entry.title: Ian McKellen works his wizardry as a 93-year-old Sherlock in ‘Mr. Holmes’

entry.title: Ian McKellen at Holmes with his Sherlock
Lawyers in theater shooting trial make final appeals to jury
entry.summary: King pleaded with jurors to believe that Holmes' mental illness was the sole cause of the attack.

entry.title: Lawyers in theater shooting trial make final appeals to jury
entry.summary: Holmes, now 27, does not dispute that he was the lone gunman who attacked the theater but pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity.

entry.title: James Holmes' trial: Things to know as jury gets case
entry.summary:
Holmes surrendered to police outside the theater.

Holmes didn't testify.

entry.title: Colorado shooting defendant James Holmes called ‘psychotic’ by his attorney
entry.summary:
Daniel King said Holmes had been mentally ill even before the 2012 attack on the movie theater in Aurora, Colo., and urged the jurors to look beyond how the gunman planned his attack.

The prosecution had earlier argued that the deliberate nature of the planning and execution of the attack showed that Holmes was not mentally ill.

"There isn't a lot of logic in what Mr. Holmes did," King said.

In his presentation, Brauchler emphasized how Holmes deliberately planned the attack to compensate for failures in his graduate school studies and in his romantic life.

entry.title: After all is said in theater attack trial, was Holmes sane?
entry.summary: Jurors in the Colorado theater shooting case soon will retreat into the largest jury room in the courthouse to determine whether Holmes was legally insane at the time of the killing spree.

entry.title: After all is said in theater attack trial, was Holmes sane?
entry.summary:
The hideous details of the attack, the heartbreaking survival stories, the signs of mental illness that Holmes showed well before the events of July 20, 2012 - they shouldn't matter.

If they agree Holmes is insane, he would be committed indefinitely to a state mental hospital.

A copy of Colorado's insanity statute will guide them in the jury room as they consider Holmes' mental state that night, analyzing his medical records, family history, police reports and journal.

entry.title: After all is said in theater attack trial, was Holmes sane?
entry.summary: The only question they must answer is whether Holmes met Colorado's threshold for an insanity verdict, by suffering from mental illness so severe that it rendered him unable to tell right from wrong at the time of the shootings.

entry.title: Defense rests case in James Holmes trial
Accused theater gunman James Holmes says he won't testify
entry.summary: Holmes has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity.

entry.title: James Holmes says he will not testify
Aurora shooting defense to wrap; Holmes declined to testify
entry.summary:
On Thursday, Holmes told Judge Carlos A. Samour Jr. he will not testify in his own defense.

Had Holmes chosen to testify, prosecutors would have been able to cross-examine him.

Samour determined that Holmes' decision not to testify was made "voluntarily and intelligently."
